prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in biology would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in biology would. Find the $3 \times 3$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$ such that
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} y \\ z \\ x + y + z \end{pmatrix}\]for all real numbers $x,$ $y,$ and $z.$
gpt_response:
Let $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix}.$  Then
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} ax + by + cz \\ dx + ey + fz \\ gx + hy + iz \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want
\[\begin{pmatrix} ax + by + cz \\ dx + ey + fz \\ gx + hy + iz \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} y \\ z \\ x + y + z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $ax + by + cz = y,$ $dx + ey + fz = z,$ and $gx + hy + iz = x + y + z.$  This gives us the equations
\begin{align*}
y &= y, \\
z &= z, \\
x + y + z &= x + y + z.
\end{align*}The first two equations tell us that $a = 0,$ $b = 1,$ $d = 0,$ $e = 0,$ $g = 0,$ and $h = 0.$  Then the third equation tells us that $c = 1,$ $f = 0,$ and $i = 1,$ so
\[\mathbf{M} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}?: Let $\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix}.$  Then
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} ax + by + cz \\ dx + ey + fz \\ gx + hy + iz \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, we want
\[\begin{pmatrix} ax + by + cz \\ dx + ey + fz \\ gx + hy + iz \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} y \\ z \\ x + y + z \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $ax + by + cz = y,$ $dx + ey + fz = z,$ and $gx + hy + iz = x + y + z.$  This gives us the equations
\begin{align*}
y &= y, \\
z &= z, \\
x + y + z &= x + y + z.
\end{align*}The first two equations tell us that $a = 0,$ $b = 1,$ $d = 0,$ $e = 0,$ $g = 0,$ and $h = 0.$  Then the third equation tells us that $c = 1,$ $f = 0,$ and $i = 1,$ so
\[\mathbf{M} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
